summary: 1/1/1970: Unknown African American assailants fired several bullets at police headquarters in Cairo, Illinois, United States.  There were no casualties, however, one bullet narrowly missed several police officers.  This attack took place during heightened racial tensions, including a Black boycott of White-owned businesses, in Cairo Illinois.
motive: To protest the Cairo Illinois Police Deparment
addnotes: The Cairo Chief of Police, William Petersen, resigned as a result of the attack.
scite1: "Police Chief Quits," Washington Post, January 2, 1970.
scite2: "Cairo Police Chief Quits; Decries Local 'Militants'," Afro-American, January 10, 1970.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

target1: Juan Maria de Lucah/Chief of Directorate of info. and intell.

summary: 1/2/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated explosives at the Pacific Gas & Electric Company Edes substation in Oakland, California, United States.  Three transformers were damaged costing an estimated $20,000 to $25,000.  There were no casualties.
propcomment: Three transformers were damaged.
addnotes: Damages were estimated to be between $20,000-$25,000.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 1/2/1970: Karl Armstrong, a member of the New Years Gang, threw a firebomb at R.O.T.C. offices located within the Old Red Gym at the University of Wisconsin in Madison, Wisconsin, United States.  There were no casualties but the fire caused around $60,000 in damages to the building.
target1: R.O.T.C. offices at University of Wisconsin, Madison
motive: To protest the War in Vietnam and the draft
propcomment: Basketball courts, weight room, swimming pool, gymnastic equipment, and lockers were destroyed.
addnotes: The New Years Gang issue a communiqu? to a local paper claiming that they perpetrated this attack.  The New Years Gang  previously attempted to firebomb the R.O.T.C. building a week earlier.  As a result of the attack, police increased their presence in Madison.  Karl Armstrong's girlfriend, Lynn Schultz, drove him to and from the Old Red Gym.  The next day Armstrong would attempt to set a fire in the Selective Service offices in Madison. (197001030001)  Karl Armstrong would be captured after participating in the deadly bombing of Sterling Hall at the University of Wisconsin on August 24, 1970.  (197008240001)
scite1: Tom Bates, "Rads: The 1970 Bombing of the Army Math Research Center at the University of Wisconsin and Its Aftermath," HarperCollinsPublishing, 1992.
scite2: David Newman, Sandra Sutherland, and Jon Stewart, "The Madison Bomb Story: The Death the FBI Saw, Heard and Won't Talk About," Mother Jones, February-March, 1979.
scite3: The Wisconsin Cartographers' Guild, "Wisconsin's Past and Present: A Historical Atlas," The University of Wisconsin Press, 2002.

summary: 1/3/1970: Karl Armstrong, a member of the New Years Gang, broke into the University of Wisconsin's Primate Lab and set a fire on the first floor of the building.  Armstrong intended to set fire to the Madison, Wisconsin, United States, Selective Service Headquarters across the street but mistakenly confused the building with the Primate Lab.  The fire caused slight damages and was extinguished almost immediately.
target1: Selective Service Headquarters in Madison Wisconsin
motive: To protest the War in Vietnam and the draft
weapdetail: Poured gasoline on the floor and lit it with a match
propcomment: Slight damage
addnotes: Karl Armstrong's girlfriend, Lynn Schultz, drove him to and from the Primate Lab.  A day earlier Armstrong would firebomb the R.O.T.C. offices at the University of Wisconsin. (197001020003)  Karl Armstrong would be captured after participating in the deadly bombing of Sterling Hall at the University of Wisconsin on August 24, 1970. (197008240001)
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Tom Bates, "Rads: The 1970 Bombing of the Army Math Research Center at the University of Wisconsin and Its Aftermath," HarperCollinsPublishing, 1992.
scite3: David Newman, Sandra Sutherland, and Jon Stewart, "The Madison Bomb Story: The Death the FBI Saw, Heard and Won't Talk About," Mother Jones, February-March, 1979.

summary: 1/6/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail into an Army Recruiting Station in Denver, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties but damages to the station were estimated at $305.
motive: Protest the draft and Vietnam War
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 1/9/1970: Unknown perpetrators set off a firebomb at the Packard Properties building in Detroit, Michigan, United States.  The facility housed federal employees.  The building was damaged but there were no casualties.
target1: Packard Properties building of Detroit Michigan
propcomment: Building was damaged
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 1/9/1970:  The Armed Commandos of Liberation claimed credit for setting a fire at the Baker's Store in Rio Piedras, Puerto Rico.  There were no casualties but the store was destroyed at a cost of $2,000,000.
corp1: American owned business in Puerto Rico
motive: To protest United States owned businesses in Puerto Rico
weapdetail: Fire set in back of store
propcomment: Store destroyed
addnotes: The fire began at 8:30 PM. The Armed Commandos of Liberation claimed the incident but authorities did not discover any evidence proving that the fire was set intentionally.
scite1: Committee on the Judiciary  United States Senate, "Terroristic Activity: The Cuban Connection in Puerto Rico; Castro's Hand in Puerto Rican and U.S. Terrorism," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "No Evidence Of Arson Found In Barkers Fire," The Virgin Islands Daily News, January 13, 1970.
scite3: "Toward People's War for Independence and Socialism in Puerto Rico: In Defense of Armed Struggle," Documents and Communiqu?s from the Revolutionary Public Independence Movement and the Armed Clandestine Movement, January 1987.

propcomment: Damages: none, attempted to detonate device and were unsuccessful (Jurists Ball)

summary: 1/12/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a pipe bomb into the vacant dean's office of James Madison High School in Brooklyn, New York, United States.  There were no casualties but the explosion caused minor damages.  Earlier in the day anti-war and pro-Black Panther statements were discovered painted outside the walls of the school.
motive: Suspected motives were to protest the Vietnam War and/or show support for the Black Panther Party and/or show support for the Young Lords.
weapdetail: Crudely made pipe bomb.  Five inches long and a half inch thick filled with gunpowder that was connected to a fuse.
propcomment: Damaged a blackboard and shattered a pane of glass.
addnotes: One half hour after the bomb explosion, an anonymous caller warned of a bomb that was going to detonated in the locker room, however this device was never found.  The inscriptions on the wall of the building were "Panthers 21," "Support Young Lords," and "Americong."  There was no history of racial violence at James Madison High School.
scite1: "Blast Damages Flatbush School," New York Times, January 13, 1970.
scite2: Linda Greenhouse, "Madison School Puzzled By Bomb," New York Times, January 18, 1970.
scite3: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 1/12/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a bomb at a General Electric factory in Rio Grande, Puerto Rico during a strike.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the factory sustained any damages.
target1: General Electric factory in Rio Grande Puerto Rico
scite1: Committee on the Judiciary  United States Senate, "Terroristic Activity: The Cuban Connection in Puerto Rico; Castro's Hand in Puerto Rican and U.S. Terrorism," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Toward People's War for Independence and Socialism in Puerto Rico: In Defense of Armed Struggle," Documents and Communiqu?s from the Revolutionary Public Independence Movement and the Armed Clandestine Movement, January 1987.

summary: 1/13/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed Fuson's Department Store in Seattle, Washington, United States.  There were no casualties but the store sustained an estimated $17,000 in damages.  Less than a week earlier, the store owner shot and killed an African American male attempting to rob the store.
motive: Retaliation for the store owner who shot and killed an African American attempting to commit a robbery at his store.
addnotes: The store was a White owned business operating in a predominantly African American neighborhood.  Before the firebombing, the Fuson's received many threats against their store.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 1/14/1970: Suspected Black militants threw two firebombs into the Champaign Police Department in Champaign, Illinois, United States.  The building was damaged and one police officer was severely burned.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.
scite3: Peter F. Nardulli and Jeffrey M. Stonecash, "Politics, Professionalism, and Urban Services," Oelgeschlager, Gunn & Hain, Publishers, Inc. 1981.

summary: 1/17/1970: Three African Americans were suspected of detonating a bomb on the Seattle University campus in Seattle, Washington, United States.  There were no casualties but the Liberal Arts and Garrand buildings sustained $2,200 in damages.
target1: Liberal Arts and Garrand buildings, Seattle University
motive: The incident took place during disturbances between the Black Student Union and the university.
propcomment: Windows were shattered at the Liberal Arts and Garrand Buildings.
addnotes: Witnesses observed three African American males running from the scene.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.
scite3: Seattle University, "1965-1975: Troubled Times," <www.seattleu.eduhistorysection6.html>

summary: 1/17/1970: Silas and Judith Bissell placed an explosive device in the vicinity of the Air Force R.O.T.C. at the University of Washington campus in Seattle, Washington, United States.  The device was discovered and subsequently disarmed.
target1: Air Force R.O.T.C. at the University of Washington
motive: The incident took place during heightened antiwar sentiments in Seattle Washington.
addnotes: Judith and Silas Bissell were both members of Students for a Democratic Society.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.
scite3: Earl Caldwell, "Fear Grows In Seattle As Police Urge F.B.I. Help On Bombings," New York Times, April 26, 1970.

summary: 1/19/1970: Unknown perpetrators ignited a fire at the Black Panther Party headquarters in Jersey City, New Jersey, United States.  Two hours later shots were fired at the building.  There were no casualties but the building sustained minor damages.
motive: Intimidate the Black Panther Party.
weapdetail: Gasoline was placed on the steps of the building and set on fire.  Between 10-30 shots were fired.
propcomment: The fire caused minor damages to the door and the front of the building.  The created caused holes in the door and the cardboard that was covering the windows.
addnotes: The building might have been shot at a second time after the Panthers evacuated the building.  The arson took place just before midnight on January 19th and the shooting took place after 1 A.M. on January 20th.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Black Panthers Say Office Was Bombed," New York Times, January 20, 1970.
scite3: "30 Shots Fired Into Office of Panthers in Jersey City," Washington Post, January 21, 1971.

corp1: Father owned chain of dept stores
gname: Armed Forces of National Liberation- Venezuela (FALN)

summary: 1/22/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated an explosive device near a private home in South Sioux City, Nebraska, United States.  There were no casualties, however, a sizable hole was left in the house and windows were broken.  This attack was one of many instances of violence in South Sioux City during the Iowa Beef Packers strike.
motive: The attack occurred during the violent Iowa Beef Packers strike in South Sioux City.
weapdetail: Dynamite thrown at foundation of home
propcomment: Sizable hole in the house and broken windows
addnotes: This attack might be linked with other episodes of strike violence in South City Nebraska (197001300001, 197001300002, 197002230001, 197002230002, 197002230003, 197002230004)
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Beef Plant Workers in Nebraska Await Call to Work After Violent Strike Ends," New York Times, April 12, 1970.

summary: 1/25/1970: Unknown perpetrators burnt down a building that was a meeting spot for African Americans in West Point, Mississippi, United States.  There were no injuries or fatalities.  The attack occurred amidst widespread disapproval of school desegregation by the White population of West Point.
target1: Building used as a meeting place for African Americans.
motive: The motive of the attack was to prevent the African American community of West Point Mississippi from organizing.
propcomment: Building burnt down
addnotes: Police, at the time suspected, that this attack was linked to dissatisfaction over integration of the schools in West Point, Mississippi but could not conclusively rule out that this incident was criminally motivated.
scite1: "Miss. City Is Desegregation Trouble Spot," Chicago Daily Defender, January 29, 1970.

summary: 1/25/1970: Responding to what authorities believe was a fake report to lure police to Manhattan, New York, United States, Patrolmen William Kivlehan and Ralph Bax were shot at from a rooftop by unknown perpetrators after they got out of their car.  Officer Kivlehan was hit five times and officer Bax was hit three times.  Both policemen survived.
target1: New York Police Officers responding to a call in Harlem
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: Nine thirty-caliber cartridges from a carbine and eleven nine-millimeter shells
propcomment: One window in a building shattered
addnotes: Police do not believe that this attack was related to the shooting of a police officer in Queens hours later (197001260003).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Martin Arnold, "Harlem Area Sealed Off As Police Hunt Snipers," New York Times, January 27, 1970.
scite3: "2 Policemen Wounded by Sniper Fire," New York Times, January 26, 1970.

summary: 1/26/1970: Unknown African American assailants, unsatisfied with the courts decision on desegregation, threw a stick of dynamite at the Clay County Courthouse in West Point, Mississippi, United States.  There were no injuries or fatalities but the windows of the building were shattered.
motive: African American opposition to the school integration plan instituted by the federal government.  The government plan closed two Black schools.
weapdetail: Several sticks of dynamite were thrown, from a car, at the courthouse.
propcomment: Windows shattered
addnotes: Police, at the time, suspected that this attack was linked to dissatisfaction over integration of the schools.  John Thomas, John Buffington, and three other Blacks were charged with conspiracy but no individual was indicted.
scite1: "Miss. City Is Desegregation Trouble Spot," Chicago Daily Defender, January 29, 1970.
scite2: "Black, White Killings in South, West Trigger Racial Skirmishes," New Pittsburgh Courier, October 30, 1971.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 1/26/1970: Police officer Joseph Blik was on foot patrol in Queens, New York, United States when two people in a car stopped to ask him for directions.  The perpetrators in the car immediately fired two shots at Officer Blik and then drove away.  Officer Blik was not hit.
target1: New York Police Officer on patrol in Forest Hills
motive: To kill police
addnotes: Police do not believe that this attack was related to the shooting of two police officers in Manhattan hours earlier (197001250002).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Martin Arnold, "Harlem Area Sealed Off As Police Hunt Snipers," New York Times, January 27, 1970.
scite3: "2 Policemen Wounded by Sniper Fire," New York Times, January 26, 1970.

summary: 1/27/1970: Unknown perpetrators broke into the Selective Service Offices located at the Citizens Bank Building in Norwalk, Ohio, United States.  The perpetrators took out the draft records and set them on fire.  The attack caused an estimated $8,800 in damages.
target1: Selective Service office in Norwalk Ohio
motive: Protest and sabotage the draft
propcomment: Smoke damage
addnotes: The perpetrators broke through the door of the building early in the morning.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Clues To Arson Sought In Norwalk," Toledo Blade, January 28, 1970.

target1: Residence of President of Penal Office

summary: 1/28/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated an explosive device at Temple De Hirsch in Seattle, Washington, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained $1,000 in damages.  During this time period, there were numerous bombings in the Seattle area.
propcomment: Small hole in the door
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Synagogue Blasted," Tri City Herald, January 25, 1970.

summary: 1/30/1970: In a series of two incidents that were possibly related, unknown perpetrators detonated an explosive device at a building in South Sioux City, Nebraska, United States.  There were no casualties but the blast damaged the foundation of the building.  This attack was one of many instances of violence in South Sioux City during the Iowa Beef Packers strike.
motive: The attack occurred during the violent Iowa Beef Packers strike in South Sioux City.
propcomment: Damaged foundation of building
addnotes: This incident might be part of a multiple attack with 197001300002.  Also, this attack might be linked with other episodes of strike violence in South City Nebraska (197002230001, 197002230002, 197002230003, 197002230004, 197001220002).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Beef Plant Workers in Nebraska Await Call to Work After Violent Strike Ends," New York Times, April 12, 1970.

summary: 1/30/1970: In a series of two incidents that were possibly related, unknown perpetrators detonated an explosive device at the A & B Boat Shop in South Sioux City, Nebraska, United States.  There were no casualties but the blast caused $2,500 in damages.  This attack was one of many instances of violence in South Sioux City during the Iowa Beef Packers strike.
motive: The attack occurred during the violent Iowa Beef Packers strike in South Sioux City.
addnotes: This incident might be part of a multiple attack with 197001300001.  Also, this attack might be linked with other episodes of strike violence in South City Nebraska (197002230001, 197002230002, 197002230003, and 197002230004).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Beef Plant Workers in Nebraska Await Call to Work After Violent Strike Ends," New York Times, April 12, 1970.

summary: 1/20/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed the premises of the Army R.O.T.C. at the University of Miami in Coral Gables, Florida, United States.  There were no casualties but an Army personal carrier was damaged.  Two firebombs did not explode.
motive: To protest the R.O.T.C. program and the War in Vietnam
weapdetail: Two firebombs ignited, at least one of them was thrown.  One of the firebombs was a rag wick set on fire stuffed in a gas tank of a parked car that burnt out.  Two other firebombs did not ignited.
propcomment: Army personnel carrier was damaged
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Firebombs Exploded In Miami," Times-News, January 30, 1970.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 1/31/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed the Police Band Building in Denver, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties but a restroom was damaged.
propcomment: Restroom damaged
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 2/1/1970: An unknown perpetrator broke into the Northeast Oregon building in Portland, Oregon, United States, which housed a Selective Service office and set fire to draft records.  About two hundred and fifty files were destroyed causing $4,189 in damage.
target1: Selective Service office Local Board No. 28 in Portland Oregon
motive: Protest and sabotage the draft
propcomment: Approximately two hundred and fifty draft records destroyed
addnotes: It is suspected that the perpetrator was attempting to look for his own draft file.  This incident did not disrupt this particular Selective Service office since there was a duplicate of all of the records on microfilm.  In a sixth month period, the Oregon Selective Service Headquarters was firebombed three other times (197005060006, 197006030001, and 197008100001).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Arsonist 'Failed,'" Eugene Register-Guard, February 4th, 1970.

summary: 2/1/1970: Unknown perpetrators fired shots at an Illinois State Police Car that was patrolling the all-Black Pyramid Courts housing development in Cairo, Illinois, United States.  Three bullets struck the police car of Officers Harold Nelson and John Abercrombie.  Neither officer was injured but the windshield of vehicle car was shattered.
target1: Illinois State Police in the Pyramid Courts housing project
motive: To protest police presence in Pyramid Courts
propcomment: Windshield of police car shattered
addnotes: This attack took place during heightened racial tensions, including a Black boycott of White-owned businesses, in Cairo Illinois.  Officer Nelson was Black and Officer Abercrombie was White.  A few days after the incident Reverend Charles Koen, a Black community leader, sent a request to the governor of Illinois that State Police patrols be removed from Pyramid Courts.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Shooting Inquiry at Cairo," The Southeast Missourian, February 2, 1970.
scite3: "Front Asks Time With Governor," The Southeast Missourian, February 3, 1970.

summary: 2/2/1970: An incendiary device was discovered at Mays department store in Manhattan, New York, United States.  The device was dismantled before it inflicted any damage.  The next day, two incendiary devices were discovered at other department stores in New York City.
scite1: "Alexander's Stores Survive 2 Bombs With No Damage," New York Times, February 4, 1970.
scite2: "Fire Bomb is Found in Alexander Store," New York Times, February 5, 1970.

summary: 2/3/1970: In a series of related attacks, an incendiary device was discovered and dismantled at Alexander's Department Store in the Bronx, New York, United States.
target1: Alexander's Department Store in the Bronx
weapdetail: Incendiary device packed in a cigarette box that included batteries, chemicals, and a flash cube that was connected to a wristwatch.
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197002030002.  An incendiary device in a cigarette package was also used by MIRA in an attacl against a store in New York City one year after this incident. (197103190002)  Many different terrorist groups targeted in New York Department Stores in early 1970s.  This attack might be linked with 197002020001 as well.
scite1: "Alexander's Stores Survive 2 Bombs With No Damage," New York Times, February 4, 1970.
scite2: "Fire Bomb is Found in Alexander Store," New York Times, February 5, 1970.

summary: 2/3/1970: In a series of related attacks, an incendiary device was ignited at Alexander's Department Store in Manhattan, New York, United States.  The device was immediately doused with water and did not cause any damage.
propcomment: The device was doused with water by a security guard immediately after it ignited
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197002030001.  The incendiary device was thought to be similar to the one in 197002030001, but it was destroyed before authorities could make any conclusions.  An incendiary device in a cigarette package was also used by MIRA in an attack against a store in New York City one year after this incident. (197103190002)  Many different terrorist groups targeted in New York Department Stores in early 1970s.  This attack might be linked with 197002020001.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Alexander's Stores Survive 2 Bombs With No Damage," New York Times, February 4, 1970.
scite3: "Fire Bomb is Found in Alexander Store," New York Times, February 5, 1970.

summary: 2/4/1970: In an attack suspected of being connected with the Iowa Beef Packer's Strike, a dynamite bomb exploded near a parked car in Akron, Ohio, United States.  There were no casualties and the car sustained only minor damages.
motive: The attack occurred during the violent Iowa Beef Packers strike.
propcomment: Minor damages
addnotes: This attack might be linked with other episodes of violence during the Iowa Beef Packers strike (197001220002, 197001300001, and 197001300002)
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 2/6/1970: Unknown anti-desegregationists detonated at least twelve dynamite bombs damaging thirty-nine vehicles, most of them school buses, in Denver, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties.
motive: Sabotage/protest the integration of Denver City Schools.
weapdetail: At least 12 dynamite bombs were set off under the gas tanks of the vehicles.
propcomment: The explosion destroyed 24 buses and 4 trucks while damaging 15 school buses and 6 other vehicles.
addnotes: School buses played a significant role in transporting Black students to integrated schools.  Approximately 1/3 of Denver's school buses were put out of commission.  Three white males were seen running from the scene shortly before the explosion, however, no perpetrators were ever apprehended.
scite1: Anthony Ripley, "Denver Blasts Destroy 24 School Buses," New York Times, February 7, 1970.
scite2: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 2/6/1970: Suspected White Racists detonated a bomb at the house of State Senator Fred Dore in Seattle, Washington, United States.  There were no casualties, but the house sustained major damages.  Dore was a White sympathizer of African American causes.
corp1: White politician who represented a Black constituency
motive: To intimidate/show dissatisfaction with White sympathizers of the African American cause.
propcomment: The house was badly damaged.
addnotes: The  general consensus among sources is that the attack was carried out by White Racists.  After the incident Senator Dore moved to another part of town.  This attack has been linked with the bombing of the home of Seattle State Legislator David Sprague (197004190004).  On the same day as this incident, a Jewish synagogue was bombed in Seattle (197002060003).
scite1: Earl Caldwell, "Fear Grows in Seattle as Police Urge F.B.I. Help on Bombings," New York Times, April 26, 1970.
scite2: Steven V. Roberts, "Bombings on Rise Over the Nation," New York Times, March 13, 1970.
scite3: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 2/6/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a bomb at a synagogue in Seattle, Washington, United States.  There were no casualties but the building as well as surrounding residences sustained minor damage.   During this time period, there were numerous bombings in the Seattle area.
propcomment: Door of synagogue damaged and windows shattered at nearby houses
addnotes: This might be linked with 197001280002.  Both were bombings occurred against synagogues in Seattle.  This incident took place on the same day that Washington State Senator Frank Dore's home was bombed (197002060002).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 2/6/1970: In a series of related events, the Armed Revolutionary Independence Movement (MIRA) claimed credit for igniting firebombs at a Selective Service office in Dorado, Puerto Rico.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the firebombs caused any damage.
target1: Selective Service office in Dorado Puerto Rico
motive: To fight imperialism and exploitation.
propcomment: It is unknown if the firebombs caused any damage
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197002060005 and 197002060006.  The three attacks occurred within 30 minutes of each other.  MIRA claimed this attack along with 197002080002 and 197002090003 in the same mimeographed sheet sent to the news media.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Puerto Rican Group Describes Bombings," New York Times, February 13, 1970.

summary: 2/6/1970: In a series of related events, the Armed Revolutionary Independence Movement (MIRA) claimed credit for igniting firebombs at a General Electric facility in Rio Piedras, Puerto Rico.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the firebombs caused any damage.
motive: To fight imperialism and exploitation.
propcomment: It is unknown if the firebombs caused any damage

summary: 2/8/1970: In a series of related events, the Armed Revolutionary Independence Movement (MIRA) claimed credit for bombing the General Electric Service Center in Queens, New York, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustains minor damages.

summary: 2/13/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated two dynamite bombs in the parking lot of the Berkeley Police Station in California, United States, during a shift change.  Seven police officers were injured, three cars were destroyed, and windows were shattered at nearby buildings.
motive: To intimidate the police.
propcomment: Three cars destroyed.  Numerous other vehicles damaged.  Windows shattered at adjacent buildings.
addnotes: The bombs detonated 30 seconds apart.  The bombs used in the attack were similar to the devices used in the attack against a police station in San Francisco three days later (197002160001).  There was a contentious City Council debate earlier in the week as to whether the police department should receive a helicopter.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Bombs Injure 2 Policemen in Berkeley," Washington Post, February 14, 1970.
scite3: "San Francisco Bomb Injured 7 Policemen," Washington Post, February 18, 1970.

summary: 7/15/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed the Chase Manhattan Bank in Manhattan, New York, United States.  There were no casualties, however, the glass doors of the building and windows were shattered.
target1: Chase Manhattan Bank, East Village Branch
propcomment: Glass door and windows shattered
addnotes: This was one of many bank bombings in New York City during 1970.
scite1: "Door of Chase Bank Is Damaged By Bomb," New York Times, July 15, 1970.
scite2: "Bank Blasted," The Montreal Gazette, July 16, 1970.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 2/15/1970: Unknown perpetrators set fire to a building housing an R.O.T.C. storage area at the University of Oregon in Eugene, Oregon, United States.  One fireman was injured fighting the blaze and the men's physical education building sustained an estimated $350,000 in damages.  The incident took place a week after the university voted to retain the R.O.T.C. program.
target1: R.O.T.C. storage area, University of Oregon
motive: To protest the University of Oregon's decision to retain the R.O.T.C. program
propcomment: R.O.T.C. storage area destroyed.  Four class rooms and two offices were destroyed.
addnotes: The fire was set in the R.O.T.C. storage area.  David Boggs was the fireman who was injured.
scite1: Mike Stahlberg, "Clues Sought for Cause of UO Fire," Eugene Register-Guard, February 17, 1970.
scite2: "Students Impede Firemen; R.O.T.C. Offices in Ruins," The Milwaukee Journal, February 17, 1970.
scite3: Emily Mosen, "The Reserve Officers' Training Corps: Protests and Perspectives on the University of Oregon Campus in 1969 and 1970," University of Oregon, March 14, 2005.

location: The incident occurred at the Hall of Justice.
summary: 2/16/1970: Four hours after a San Francisco Police Station was bombed in California, United States, a sniper took aim at three police officers.  However, police fired at the sniper before he could get a shot off.  The sniper and a companion fled the scene before being apprehended.
motive: To intimidate the police.
addnotes: This attack is linked with 197002160001.  The sniper and his companion were described as hippie types.
scite1: "San Francisco Bomb Injured 7 Policemen," Washington Post, February 18, 1970.

summary: 2/17/1970: A day after bombings in San Francisco and Berkeley, twenty-four sticks of dynamite were discovered at Walter Boysen Paint Company in Oakland, California, United States.  The bombs never detonated.
addnotes: The dynamite was found a day after 197002160001, 197002160002, and 197002160003.  Police reported that the target was apparently random and could not confirm whether this was connected to the previous attacks.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "San Francisco Bomb Injured 7 Policemen," Washington Post, February 18, 1970.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 2/17/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a power pole in Buckeystown, Maryland, United States.  There were no casualties, however, as a result of the bombing, five-hundred homes and two industrial facilities lost power.  Windows were also shattered in buildings a quarter of a mile a way.
target1: Power supply of the Frederick Maryland area
propcomment: Over 500 homes and 2 industries temporarily lost power.  Windows were shattered at buildings as far as one quarter of a mile away.
addnotes: The two industries that lost power were Todd Steel and East Alco Aluminum Plant.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 2/17/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a bomb at Covington High School in Louisiana, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained minor damages.  The bombing took place six months before the school was integrated.
motive: Suspected motive was to protest school integration.
propcomment: 4-foot hole blown into a wall, stall partitions damaged, and windows shattered.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

motive: Protest the War in Vietnam

summary: 2/20/1970: Unknown perpetrators ignited a firebomb at the Columbia University International Law Library in Manhattan, New York, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained slight damages.

propcomment: Minor damage

summary: 2/21/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a firebomb at a police car in front of the Charles Street Police Station in Greenwich, New York, United States.  Another bomb was thrown to the pavement  seventy-five feet away.  The attacks caused no damages or casualties.
scite1: Emanuel Perlmutter, "Justice Murtagh's Home Target of 3 Fire Bombs," New York Times, February 22, 1970.
scite2: "Bombs Are Exploded at Home of N.Y. Panther Trial Judge," New York Times, February 21, 1970.

summary: 2/21/1970: Two Military Recruiting Stations in the vicinity of Brooklyn College were firebombed by unknown perpetrators in New York, United States.  There were no casualties but the recruiting stations sustained minor damages before the fire was extinguished.
target1: Army Recruiting Booth and Navy Recruiting Booth
propcomment: The booths were scorched
scite1: Emanuel Perlmutter, "Justice Murtagh's Home Target of 3 Fire Bombs," New York Times, February 22, 1970.
scite2: "Bombs Are Exploded at Home of N.Y. Panther Trial Judge," New York Times, February 21, 1970.

summary: 2/21/1970: The Weathermen claimed credit for bombing the residence of State Supreme Court Justice John Murtagh New York, United States.  The attack caused no casualties but the house sustained minor damages.  Judge Murtagh was presiding over a trial of thirteen Black Panther members at the time.    Anti-Vietnam war and pro-Black Panther graffiti was left at the scene of the attack.
motive: Protest Vietnam War and show support for Black Panthers.
weapdetail: Gasoline in bottles detonated by firecrackers
propcomment: Brick wall was partially scorched and several panes in a window were damaged.
addnotes: It was suspected that this attack might have been related to 197002210003, 197002210004, and 197002200002.  However, the Weathermen only claimed credit for this attack in a letter to the New York Times, and did not mention participation in any other attacks on February 21. Written in front of the house was graffiti stating "Free Panther 21" and "Vietcong Have Won." The bombs were placed on the front doorway, next to a window, and under the Murtagh's car.  Murtagh and his family were placed in the protection of the police as a result of the attack.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Emanuel Perlmutter, "Justice Murtagh's Home Target of 3 Fire Bombs," New York Times, February 22, 1970.
scite3: Bernardine Dohrn, "An End to Violence?" New York Times, January 19, 1971.

summary: 2/21/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a firebomb into the residence of James C. Perrill in Denver, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties and it is unknown if the house was damaged.  The attack occurred during heightened racial tensions due to the integration of Denver City Schools and Perrill was  a conservative school board member.
motive: Protest anti-integrationists of the Denver City Schools.
propcomment: It is unknown if the firebomb caused any damage
addnotes: This is one of many attacks in Denver resulting from school integration.  Other incidents include 197002060001 and 197002240002.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Anthony Ripley, "Colorado Weighs Blast Controls," New York Times, March 9, 1970.

summary: 2/22/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw kerosene flare pots at the Wari House Dormitory which housed the Black Women's Cooperative at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York, United States.  The incendiary tossed at the dormitory failed to ignite, but an incendiary thrown through the window of a car parked in front of the dormitory burst into flames and caused minor damages to the vehicle.  There were no casualties.
motive: To intimidate the African American community at Cornell University
propcomment: Car sustained minor damages and a broken window
addnotes: This attack occurred amidst heightened racial tensions at Cornell University.  A year earlier, unknown perpetrator burnt a cross in front of the Wari House dormitory.  Five weeks after the attack the Africana Studies and Research Center on campus was firebombed (197004010002).
scite1: "Flare Pot Hurled at Cornell House," New York Times, February 23, 1970.
scite2: Richard Phalon, "Fire Destroys the Black Studies Center at Cornell," New York Times, April 2, 1970.
scite3: Michael T. Kaufman, "Court Enjoins Violence at Cornell; Curfew Set," New York Times, April 10, 1970.

summary: 2/22/1970: Karl Armstrong, a member of the New Years Gang, attempted to bomb the Wisconsin Power and Light substation in Prairie du Sac, Wisconsin, United States.  Carrying thirteen sticks of dynamite he broke into the substation, but fled the scene when a night security guard arrived unexpectedly.  The substation supplied power to the Badger Ammunition Plant.
target1: Wisconsin Power and Light Company substation, Prairie du Sac
motive: To sabotage the Badger Ammunition Plant
weapdetail: Thirteen sticks of dynamite attached to a battery operated device
addnotes: The New Years Gang attempted to bomb the Wisconsin Ammunition Plant weeks earlier. (197001050001)  Karl Armstrong would be captured after participating in the deadly bombing of Sterling Hall at the University of Wisconsin on August 24, 1970.  (197008240001)
scite1: Tom Bates, "Rads: The 1970 Bombing of the Army Math Research Center at the University of Wisconsin and Its Aftermath," HarperCollinsPublishing, 1992.
scite2: David Newman, Sandra Sutherland, and Jon Stewart, "The Madison Bomb Story: The Death the FBI Saw, Heard and Won't Talk About," Mother Jones, February-March, 1979.
scite3: The Wisconsin Cartographers' Guild, "Wisconsin's Past and Present: A Historical Atlas," The University of Wisconsin Press, 2002.

summary: 2/23/1970: In a series of related attacks, unknown perpetrators bombed four separate power transmission poles in the Dakota City and Sioux City areas in Nebraska, United States.  There were no casualties and none of the dynamite blasts broke off any of the poles.   These attacks were one of many instances of violence in South Sioux City during the Iowa Beef Packers strike.
target1: Power Transmission Pole in the Dakota City/Sioux City area
motive: The attack occurred during the violent Iowa Beef Packers strike in South Sioux City.
propcomment: None of the poles broke off
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 2/23/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a dynamite bomb in front of the Selective Service Headquarters in Tucson, Arizona, United States. There were no casualties, however, all of the windows of the building shattered.

summary: 2/24/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a pipe bomb in front of the house of Wilfred Keyes in Denver, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties, however, the front porch was destroyed and many windows were shattered.  Keyes was the lead plaintiff in a court case calling for the desegregation of Denver City Schools.
motive: Protest the desegregation of Denver City Schools.
propcomment: Front porch was destroyed and windows in the house were shattered
addnotes: This is one of many attacks in Denver resulting from school integration.  Other incidents include 197002060001 and 197002210006.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Anna Alejo, "Alejo: Keys to Success," Rocky Mountain News, January 28, 2006.
scite3: James Brooke, "Court Says Denver Can End Forced Busing," New York Times, September 17, 1995.

summary: 2/24/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail into the Armory at the University of Illinois, Champaign-Urbana, United States.  There were no casualties but the firebomb caused $2,000 in damages.  The offices of the R.O.T.C. were located in the Armory
motive: Protest secret government research at the University of Illinois and the R.O.T.C. program.
weapdetail: Molotov cocktail thrown through the window of the Armory
addnotes: The attack occurred a day after the Illiac project was approved by the University. Of Illinois  The project brought a high powered computer to campus that would be used mostly for government research.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Patrick D. Kennedy, "Reactions Against the Vietnam War and Military-Related Targets on Campus: The University of Illinois as a Case Study, 1965-1972," Illinois Historical Journal, 1991.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 2/27/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a bomb in the Behavioral Sciences Building at the University of Colorado at Boulder in Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties but the building was damaged.
motive: Protesting scholarship money that was set aside for minorities but had yet to be awarded
addnotes: This attack occurred the week before first lady Pat Nixon planned on visiting the University of Colorado.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Marie Smith, "Heavy Security Highlights Pat's Colorado Visit," Washington Post, March 5, 1970.
scite3: Anthony Ripley, "Colorado Weighs Blast Controls," New York Times, March 9, 1970.

summary: 3/1/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed the office of the Air Force R.O.T.C. at the University of Colorado in Boulder, Colorado, United States.  There were no casualties but the R.O.T.C. training facility sustained an estimated $2,000 in damages.
target1: Air Force R.O.T.C. at University of Colorado
motive: Protest the Vietnam War and the R.O.T.C.
weapdetail: Explosive device made with 5-gallon can of gasoline
propcomment: Door destroyed and walls damaged
addnotes: The perpetrators painted signs on nearby the building saying "Imperialism Burns" and "Vietnam Napalm R.O.T.C.." This attack occurred the week before first lady Pat Nixon planned on visiting the University of Colorado.  The incident also occurred on the same day as 197003010006 and 197003010007.  No records of the R.O.T.C. were destroyed in the attack.  This incident might also be related to the minority fees issue like 197002270001.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Colorado R.O.T.C. Blast Attributed to Arsonists," Washington Post, March 3, 1970.
scite3: Robert W. Patterson, "Crime & the American Response," Facts on File, 1973

summary: 3/3/1970: Four left wing radicals set off a dynamite bomb at a post office in Seattle, Washington, United States.  There were no casualties but the building and a vehicle were damaged.
target1: Post Office in Seattle's University District
propcomment: Building and vehicle damaged
addnotes: Two of the perpetrators were members of Students for a Democratic Society and the other two perpetrators were known sympathizers of the organization.  There is a source claiming that one of the perpetrators of the attack, Jeff Desmond, was actually working for the Federal Bureau of Investigation (See: Dave Dellinger, "More Power Than We Know: The People's Movement Toward Democracy").
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 3/4/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed a time bomb in a Barracks at the Oakland Army Base in California, United States.  The bomb was subsequently discovered and disarmed. The base was used as a departing point for United States troops heading to Vietnam.
motive: Sabotage the US Army war efforts and protest the Vietnam War
weapdetail: Two and one half pound block of C-4 wired to a commercial blasting cap and timing device
addnotes: When the bomb was discovered the barracks were evacuated.  This incident might be related with 197003040002.  They both occurred on the same day in a distance of around thirty miles from each other.  However, different types of explosive devices were used.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Army Disarms Time Bomb at Base in Oakland," Washington Post, March 5, 1970.
scite3: "Bomb Found and Disarmed At Oakland Army Base," New York Times, March 5, 1970.

summary: 3/5/1970: Unknown Puerto Rican Nationalists assassinated two United States Navy personal stationed in San Juan, Puerto Rico. motive: To protest United States presence in Puerto Rico and revenge the death of Antonia Martinez Lagares
addnotes: Conflicting reports attribute the incident to the Armed Commandos of Liberation and the Armed Revolutionary Independence Movement (MIRA).

summary: 3/9/1970: A bomb exploded in the car of Ralph Featherstone and William Payne, members of the Student non-violent Coordinating Committee and supporters of H. Rap Brown, while they were driving in Bel Air, Maryland, United States.  Both men died as a result of the blast.  Police suspected that the bomb exploded prematurely and was intended for H. Rap Brown's trial scheduled to be held  at the Harford County Courthouse   Many members of the radical Black community believed that the bomb was set off by White Racists or the police.  The next day, a bomb was detonated at Dorchester County Courthouse, the original location of Brown's trial, by an unknown perpetrator.
motive: The suspected motive was to disrupt the trial of H. Rap Brown
weapdetail: Police believed that the bomb had an electric battery
propcomment: Car was damaged
addnotes: This attack is linked with 197003100002.  H. Rap Brown was charged with arson and inciting a riot.  However, he never showed up for his trial and was finally apprehended in 1972.  The bombings occurred at a time of a lot of racial tension in Maryland.   Immediately after the bombing, there were numerous bomb threats to public buildings in the Baltimore and Washington DC areas.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Homer Bigart, "Maryland Hunts Woman In Blast," New York Times, March 12, 1970.
scite3: Peter A. Jay, "Bomb Threats in Area," Washington Post, March 13, 1970.

propcomment: Damages: explosion/time bomb, none, fuses failed and device failed to detonate (court building)

Rap Brown was originally scheduled to be held.  There were no casualties but the building sustained extensive damages.
motive: To disrupt the trial of H. Rap Brown
propcomment: Thirty foot hole blown into a brick wall at the corner of the courthouse
addnotes: Police were unsure if the perpetrator acted out in support or defiance of H. Rap Brown.  This attack is linked with 197003090006.  H. Rap Brown was charged with arson and inciting a riot.  However, he never showed up for his trial and was finally apprehended in 1972.  The bombings occurred at a time of a lot of racial tension in Maryland.   Immediately after the bombing, there were numerous bomb threats to public buildings in the Baltimore and Washington DC areas.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Homer Bigart, "Maryland Hunts Woman In Blast," New York Times, March 12, 1970.
scite3: Peter A. Jay, "Bomb Threats in Area," Washington Post, March 13, 1970.

summary: 3/12/1970: In a series of related attacks, the Revolutionary Force 9 claimed credit for the bombing of the Mobil Oil Company Building in Manhattan, New York, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained heavy structural damage.  The Revolutionary Force 9 claimed that the Mobil Oil Company was an "enem(y) of human life" because it profited off of the Vietnam War.
motive: Protest the Vietnam War and companies profiting from the war
propcomment: Heavy structural damage
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197003120001 and 197003120002.  The bomb was placed in the hallway on the 34th floor.  The Revolutionary Force 9 called the police to ward authorities of the bomb before it detonated.  The RF9 also later sent a letter to United Press International after the explosion listing their grievances.  The group also called in bomb threats to many other buildings in New York City leading to numerous evacuations.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 3/14/1970: Two crewmen on the SS Columbia Eagle, Clyde William McKay Jr. and Leonard Glatkowski, hijacked the ship which debarked from Long Beach, California, United States towards Thailand.  The ship was transporting munitions that were to be used by the US military in the Vietnam War.  Twenty four crewmen were released from the ship immediately after the hijacking while thirteen were held on board as the ship was diverted to Cambodia.  The next day the SS Columbia reached Cambodia and the two perpetrators attempted attain asylum.  After many negotiations, the ship and crew were allowed to return to the United States on April 8th and McKay and Glatkowski remained in Cambodia.
motive: To impede the US war effort and protest the Vietnam War
weapdetail: Semiautomatic pistol, revolver, and fake bomb
addnotes: McKay and Glatkowski hijacked the ship by detaining the captain with their handguns and claiming that there was a bomb on board.  The device turned out to be fake.  Glatkowski would eventually return to the United States and was sentenced to a ten year prison sentence.  McKay would never return to the United States and his whereabouts remain unknown.  This was the first mutiny in the United States Navy in 150 years.  The ship was eventually returned to the United States with all of its cargo.
scite1: "Mystery of the SS Columbia Eagle Hijacking," Vietnam Magazine, February, 2001.
scite2: Tad Szulc, "U.S. Arms Ship to Thailand Seized by 'Men With Guns,'" New York Times, March 16, 1970.
scite3: "U. S. Arms Ship, Freed, Leaves Cambodia," New York Times, April 9, 1970.

summary: 3/17/1970: Suspected members of the Chicano Liberation Front detonated two bombs in administration offices at Roosevelt High School in Los Angeles, California, United States.  There were no casualties and the bombs caused little damage.
motive: To protest the poor quality of education at a school district made up primarily of Mexican-Americans.
propcomment: Little damages to administrative offices
addnotes: There were three other incidents also protesting the quality of education at Roosevelt High School (197004080003, 197004150004, and 197004150005).  Moreover, the school was the target of many demonstrations during this time period.  The Chicano Liberation Front claimed credit for the incident in a tape recording sent to the Los Angeles Free Press.  The CLF stated that they were "fed up with our people being treated like dogs." However, authorities could not confirm if the CLF actually committed the attack.
scite1: "Arsonists Blamed in $100,000 Roosevelt High School Blaze," Los Angeles Times, April 9, 1970.
scite2: Paul Houston and Franz Rodriguez, "Chicano Militants Reportedly Claim 28 Bombings in L.A.," Los Angeles Times, August 14, 1971.

Police suspected that this incident might have been politically motivated as no money was stolen from Gordin's wallet.

addnotes: The police were unsure if this incident was an attempted robbery, with the perpetrators too frightened to take the targets money, or if it was an assassination.

summary: 3/22/1970: In a series of related attacks, a member of the Black Panther Party detonated a pipe bomb at the brokerage firm Nagler, Weissman & Co. in the Bronx, New York, United States.  There were no casualties but the door and windows of the building were damaged.
motive: Revolutionary movement against the financial establishment
propcomment: Door and windows of building damaged.  Windows of adjacent buildings also damaged.
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197003220002 and 197003220003.  Police believed that 197003220001 and 197003220002 were carried out by Godwin Bernard, a member of the Black Panther Party.  He was injured when a bomb accidentally blew up in his apartment in what the police determined was a bomb factory.  Police accused his roommate Ishmael Brown, who died in the apartment blast, to be the perpetrator of 197003220003.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 3/22/1970: In a series of related attacks, a member of the Black Panther Party placed a pipe bomb on the window ledge of Chase-Manhattan Bank in the Bronx, New York, United States.  Police discovered and disarmed the time bomb.
motive: Revolutionary movement against the financial establishment
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197003220001 and 197003220003.  Police believed that 197003220001 and 197003220002 were carried out by Godwin Bernard, a member of the Black Panther Party.  He was injured when a bomb accidentally blew up in his apartment in what the police determined was a bomb factory.  Police accused his roommate Ishmael Brown, who died in the apartment blast, to be the perpetrator of 197003220003.  There was a pipe bomb placed in the same bank two weeks later (197004020002).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Michael Knight, "15 at the Electric Circus Injured in Bomb Explosion," New York Times, March 23, 1970.
scite3: Lawrence Van Gelder, "Injured Bombing Suspect Is Arraigned in Hospital," New York Times, August 12, 1970.

summary: 3/22/1970: In a series of related attacks, a suspected member of the Black Panther Party detonated a pipe bomb at the Electric Circus Discotheque in Manhattan New York, United States.  Seventeen people were injured and the building sustained minor damages.
weapdetail: Pipe bomb made of dynamite and small caliber ammunition with a clock detonator
propcomment: Portable stage destroyed
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197003220001 and 197003220002.  Originally the police believed that the attack was part of a dispute between Hells Angels, but eventually police accused Ishmael Brown, a member of the Black Panther Party, of being the perpetrator.   The Black Panther Party denied any involvement in the incident.  Brown was killed when a bomb accidentally blew up in his apartment in what the police determined was a bomb factory.  Police accused his roommate Godwin Bernard, who was injured in the apartment blast, of being the perpetrator in 197003220001 and 197003220002

summary: 3/31/1970: In a series of related incidents, a letter bomb protesting the draft was sent to Curtis W. Tarr, the head of the Selective Services in Washington D.C., United States.  The bomb was intercepted and dismantled.
motive: To protest against the draft.
weapdetail: The explosives within the letter bomb were strong enough to blow off a persons fingers.  The detonator contained a mousetrap which experts believed would not have been powerful enough to trigger the explosive.
addnotes: This was part of multiple attacks with incident 197003210001.  Both bombs were sent from Seattle and the letter bomb addressed to President Nixon stated that the Selective Service Offices were "next."

summary: 4/1/1970: Unknown perpetrators started a fire at the building that houses the Africana Studies and Research Center at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained an estimated $100,000 in damages.
corp1: Africana Studies and Research Center, Cornell University
target1: Building housing Africana Studies and Research Center
motive: To intimidate the African American community at Cornell University
propcomment: Upper two stories and roof of building damaged.  Records and research material destroyed.
addnotes: This attack occurred amidst heightened racial tensions at Cornell University.  Five weeks earlier the Black Woman's Cooperative on campus was firebombed (197002220001).  In response to the attack, 100 African American Cornell students looted the campus book store and turned over two cars.  These students were disappoint with how the university handled the situation,  As a result of the disturbances, a curfew was established on campus.
scite1: Richard Phalon, "Fire Destroys the Black Studies Center at Cornell," New York Times, April 2, 1970.
scite2: Paul L. Montgomery, "100 Cornell Negro Students Loot New Campus Store," New York Times, April 7, 1970.

addnotes: Classes continued in the Naval R.O.T.C. building even while it was being repaired.  Less than a week later the office of the dean of students at Rice University was destroyed by a firebomb (197004050007).

summary: 4/8/1970: Suspected members of the Chicano Liberation Front set fire to the administration building at Roosevelt High School in Los Angeles, California, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained over $100,000 in damages.
motive: To protest the poor quality of education at a school district made up primarily of Mexican-Americans.
propcomment: Vice principal's offices and administrative offices destroyed.  Several classrooms damaged.
addnotes: There were three other incidents also protesting the quality of education at Roosevelt High School (197003170002, 197004150005, and 197004150005).  Moreover, the school was the target of many demonstrations during this time period.  The fire was discovered at 5:00 AM.  A pile of books and magazines soaked in oil in the library were also discovered untouched by the fire.   The Chicano Liberation Front claimed credit for the incident in a tape recording sent to the Los Angeles Free Press.  The CLF stated that they were "fed up with our people being treated like dogs." However, authorities could not confirm if the CLF actually committed the attack.
scite1: "Arsonists Blamed in $100,000 Roosevelt High School Blaze," Los Angeles Times, April 9, 1970.
scite2: "2 School Buildings Hit by Fires; Loss $95,000," Los Angeles Times, April 16, 1970.
scite3: Paul Houston and Franz Rodriguez, "Chicano Militants Reportedly Claim 28 Bombings in L.A.," Los Angeles Times, August 14, 1971.

summary: 4/15/1970: In a series of related attacks, suspected members of the Chicano Liberation Front set fire to the Board of Education administration building in Los Angeles, California, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained $75,000 in damages.

motive: To protest the poor quality of education at a school district made up primarily of Mexican-Americans.

addnotes: This is part of a multiple incident with 197004150005.  There were two other incidents also protesting the quality of education at Roosevelt High School (197003170002 and 197004080003). summary: 4/16/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed railroad tracks leading to the American Potash Plant in Trona, California, United States.  There were no casualties but the tracks were partially damaged.  At the time, the American Potash Plant of Trona was the scene of a major workers strike.
propcomment: Railroad tracks partially destroyed
addnotes: Other attacks in Trona during the American Potash Plant strike include 197004050004, 197004050005, 197004140002 197004220001, and 197005210001
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

summary: 4/17/1970: Suspected members of the Black Panther Party ambushed a police paddy wagon carrying two police officers and four prisoners in Oakland, California, United States.  Both police officers were critically wounded.  In the ensuing car chase, the perpetrators threw fragmentation grenades at police vehicles causing major damage.  Two of the assailants were eventually captured.
motive: To kill police
propcomment: Police vehicles heavily damaged
addnotes: The Black Panther Party denied involvement in the attack, however, one of the captured assailants, Lewis R. Williams, was a captain in the BPP.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "5 Killed by Tornado in Mississippi," Washington Post, April 20, 1970.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 4/19/1970: In a simultaneous bombing campaign, suspected White Racists detonated an explosive device at the Japanese Presbyterian Church in Seattle, Washington, United States.  There were no casualties and the church sustained $2,000 in damages.
motive: To intimidate/show dissatisfaction with White sympathizers of the African American cause.
weapdetail: All four bombs went off in a span of 90 minutes.
addnotes: This was part of a multiple attack 197004190002, 197004190003, and 197004190004.  Although leftists, rightists, Blacks, and Whites have been accused of being perpetrators of the bombings, the general consensus is that the attack was carried out by White Racists.  This attack had a great psychological affect on the city of Seattle.  The mayor enforced the notion that the citizens of the Emerald City were "frightened" and needed answers.
scite1: Earl Caldwell, "Fear Grows in Seattle as Police Urge F.B.I. Help on Bombings," New York Times, April 26, 1970.
scite2: "4 Buildings Bombed in Seattle," Washington Post, April 21, 1970.
scite3: Carole Beers, "David Sprague, Former Legislator Who Was Radical Thinker, Gadfly," Seattle Times, June 28, 1997.

corp1: Realty office that employed African Americans
motive: To intimidate/show dissatisfaction with White sympathizers of the African American cause.
weapdetail: All four bombs went off in a span of 90 minutes.
addnotes: This was part of a multiple attack 197004190001, 197004190003, and 197004190004.  Although leftists, rightists, Blacks, and Whites have been accused of being perpetrators of the bombings, the general consensus is that the attack was carried out by White Racists. There was an attempted bombing against the same realty office a month later (197005150004).

scite3: Carole Beers, "David Sprague, Former Legislator Who Was Radical Thinker, Gadfly," Seattle Times, June 28, 1997.

summary: 4/19/1970: In a simultaneous bombing campaign, suspected White Racists detonated an explosive device at the house of State Legislator David G. Sprague in Seattle, Washington, United States.  There were no casualties and the house sustained $1,000 in damages.
corp1: White politician who represents a Black constituency
motive: To intimidate/show dissatisfaction with White sympathizers of the African American cause.
weapdetail: All four bombs went off in a span of 90 minutes.
propcomment: The house was slightly damaged.  16 windows were shattered.
addnotes: This was part of a multiple attack with 197004190001, 197004190002, and 197004190003.  Although leftists, rightists, Blacks, and Whites have been accused of being perpetrators of the bombing, the general consensus is that the attack was carried out by White Racists.  This attack had a great psychological affect on the city of Seattle.  The mayor enforced the notion that the citizens of the Emerald City were "frightened" and needed answers.  Two months before this attack, the Seattle home of State Senator Fred Dore, a white legislator in a Black community, was also bombed (197002060002).

summary: 4/19/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed a pipe bomb in a corrections officer's car parked outside of the House of Detention in Queens, New York, United States, where ten Black Panthers members were held.  The bomb failed to explode and was discovered  after an unknown individual phoned the police stating "we're going to blow up the jail in a half hour.  Free the Panther 21."
motive: To coerce the government to free the Panther 21 from prison.
weapdetail: Lighted cigarette attached to bomb fuse
addnotes: The lighted cigarette burned out before detonating the bomb.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Bomb Found at Jail, Dynamite at a Bank," New York Times, April 20, 1970.

summary: 4/20/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed the Student Union at the University of Kansas, Lawrence, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained approximately $3,000,000 in damages.
motive: This attack occurred during heightened racial tensions in Lawrence Kansas.
propcomment: The roof caved in and the top two floors of the buildings were gutted
addnotes: Authorities were unsure whether the perpetrators were Black or White.  After the attack, a curfew was instituted in Lawrence and the National Guard was called in.  Before the fire broke out, there were reports of loud explosions at the Student Union.
scite1: Rusty L. Monhollon, "This is America? The Sixties in Lawrence, Kansas," Palgrave, 2002.
scite2: Deborah C. Kidwell, "Building the Vietnam Veterans Memorial at the University of Kansas," Kansas History: A Journal of the Central Plains, 2007.
scite3: "Curfew Ordered in Illinois Town," Baltimore Sun, April 25, 1970.

location: Intersection of Wabash Ave. and Sentinel Ave.
summary: 4/21/1970:  Unknown perpetrators threw two Molotov Cocktails into a Bank of America branch in Los Angeles,  California, United States.  Another firebomb thrown into the facility did not explode.  There were no casualties but the building sustained an estimated $30,000 in damages.
target1: Boyle Heights branch of Bank of America in Los Angeles
motive: Bank of America was perceived to symbolize the "capitalist exploitation of the little man."
addnotes: The incident took place around 2:30 AM.  After the firebombs ignited, three people were witnessed fleeing the scene in a car.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Boyle Heights Bank Set Afire; Damage Estimated at $30,000," Los Angeles Times, April 22, 1970.

summary: 4/22/1970: Two women failed in their attempts to ignite a gasoline bomb at the University of Illinois' Police Station in Urbana, United States.
addnotes: The failed attack occurred one week after demonstrations against the R.O.T.C. at the University of Illinois.
scite1: Patrick D. Kennedy, "Reactions Against the Vietnam War and Military-Related Targets on Campus: The University of Illinois as a Case Study, 1965-1972," Illinois Historical Journal, 1991.

summary: 4/22/1970: Unknown perpetrators set off two firebombs at Redlands University in California, United States.  A Molotov cocktail destroyed offices in the administrative building and a bottle filled with inflammable liquid caused minor damages to a bathroom in the Hall of Letters.  There were no casualties but the total damage was estimated at $40,000.
target1: Administrative building and Hall of Letters, Redlands University
weapdetail: Molotov cocktail and a soft drink bottle filled with an inflammable liquid lit by matches
propcomment: The offices of the dean of men, dean of women and vice president of students affairs were destroyed.  Men's bathroom in Hall of Science sustained minor damages.
addnotes: The president of the University of Redlands, Dr. George Armacost, did not believe that the attack was perpetrated by students at the university.
scite1: "Firebomb Suspected As Cause In Redlands University Fire," The Bulletin, April 22, 1970.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 4/23/1970: In a series of four related incidents, the Armed Commandos of Liberation claimed credit for placing bombs that were discovered in a U.S. Naval Relay Power Station in Puerto Rico. Cumulatively, fifty-one out of fifty-three bombs failed to explode with the remaining two bombs causing minor damage.
motive: To cripple the telecommunications facilities of Puerto Rico
weapdetail: 51 bombs were found minutes before they were set to explode.
propcomment: In the four attacks, cumulatively, only two bombs exploded causing minor damage.
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197004230002, 197004230003, and 197004230004.  The overall goal of the bombings were to cripple Puerto Rican telecommunication facilities.  No information could be found describing a specific breakdown of how many bombs were placed at each target.  The Armed Commandos of Liberation claimed that the attacks caused more damage than what the media reported.  Specifically, the ACL claimed that the police microwave communications were destroyed.   This incident took place at the same time that the La Liga Socialista Puertorriquena led a strike against General Electric in Puerto Rico.
scite1: "51 Bombs Dismantled in Puerto Rico" Washington Post, April 24, 1970.
scite2: "San Juan Bombs Hit Police Radios" Washington Post, April 29, 1970.
scite3: "Toward People's War for Independence and Socialism in Puerto Rico: In Defense of Armed Struggle," Documents and Communiqu?s from the Revolutionary Public Independence Movement and the Armed Clandestine Movement, January 1987.

summary: 4/24/1970:  Unknown perpetrators threw firebombs into two separate wings of the Center for Advanced Studies of Behavioral Sciences Building at Stanford University in Palo Alto, California, United States.  There were no casualties but there was an estimated $100,000 in damages not including lost research.
target1: Center for Advanced Studies in Behavioral Sciences
motive: Protest the presence of the R.O.T.C. at Stanford University.
weapdetail: Two firebombs thrown through windows in separate parts of the building
propcomment: Damages to two separate wings of the building.  The research of ten scholars was destroyed.
addnotes: The attack occurred three hours after a sit-in at Stanford University protesting the R.O.T.C..  World renowned scholar M. N. Srinivas lost his lifework on the Indian caste system as a result of the fire.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
